column2: highlighting his pledge to send people to Mars by the 2030s

column7: with the ultimate ambition to one day remain there for an extended time.""

column1: 1	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-court-taxes-idUSKCN12B1QD	U.S. Supreme Court turns away companies in California tax dispute	"
By Lawrence Hurley
| WASHINGTON

WASHINGTON The U.S. Supreme Court on Tuesday rejected a challenge by Procter & Gamble Co and other companies to the way California imposes taxes on businesses that operate in multiple states.The justices left in place a December 2015 ruling by the California Supreme Court that California is not bound by a 1967 agreement between states that set a formula for calculating taxes. California
column2: which joined the Multistate Tax Compact in 1974
column3: changed the formula in 1993.California has since withdrawn from the state compact.

column1: Several companies
column2: including two Procter & Gamble subsidiaries
column3: Kimberly-Clark Worldwide Inc and Merck KGaA subsidiary Sigma-Aldrich Corp
column4: sued in 2010 after being denied refunds for the tax they paid between 1993 and 2005. The companies said they overpaid their taxes by $34 million.Lawyers for the companies had said $750 million in potential tax refunds in California and additional amounts in other states were at stake in the case.

column1: Many states have moved away from the Multistate Tax Compact formula. To favor and attract businesses within their borders
column2: these states have rearranged the way they tax business income so that in-state businesses pay less and out-of-state businesses pay more.

column1: (Reporting by Lawrence Hurley; Editing by Will Dunham)"
2	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-khan-idUSKCN12B1J8	Father of U.S. war hero attacks Trump's comment at debate	"
WASHINGTON Khizr Khan
column2: the father of a decorated American soldier killed in Iraq
column3: lashed out at Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump on Tuesday for saying his son would still be alive if Trump had been president at the time.""For this candidate to put his political expediency ahead of any realization of pain and suffering of the families is shameful
column4: Khan said in an interview with CNN.The New York businessman raised the name of U.S. Army Captain Humayun Khan in a Sunday night presidential debate while  criticizing Democratic rival Hillary Clinton for voting in favor of the 2003 invasion of Iraq when she was a U.S. senator.""If I was president at that time he would be alive today
column5: Trump said. Despite his assertion that he always opposed the war
column6: Trump had expressed support for it in a 2002 interview.

column1: Khizr Khan had delivered a speech to the Democratic National Convention in July showcasing his son's military service and criticizing Trump's campaign call for a temporary ban on Muslims entering the country.Trump responded at the time by questioning whether Khan's wife
column2: Ghazala Khan
column3: was not ""allowed"" to speak when she appeared next to her husband on the stage
column4: an insinuation of some conservative form of Islam that embroiled the candidate in an unpopular dispute with the Muslim parents of a fallen war hero.

column1: The Khans were stunned to hear Trump bring up the name of their son
column2: who was killed in 2004
column3: in Sunday's nationally televised debate

column5: we were saddened for such disingenuous expression of his thinking and of his feeling

column1: Trump has said he has modified his call for a ban on Muslims entering the country to a plan for ""extreme vetting."" (Reporting by Doina Chiacu; Editing by Frances Kerry)"
3	http://reuters.com/article/us-france-usa-fines-idUSKCN12B1EK	U.S. must stop judicial 'extortion' of corporate Europe
column2: French lawmakers say	"

column1: By Michel Rose
| PARIS

PARIS Europe should challenge the United States over its increasingly aggressive use of extraterritorial laws that have cost European companies - especially banks - billions in fines and other settlements
column2: a French parliamentary report said.Still reeling from the $9 billion fine its biggest bank
column3: BNP Paribas
column4: had to pay U.S. authorities over violations of American sanctions against other countries
column5: the French government has criticized in recent years what it considers the over-reach of the U.S. legal system.Paris's main objections center on the U.S. Department of Justice's broad interpretation of what it considers its jurisdiction.This sphere of influence can include transactions between non-Americans outside the U.S. where the U.S. dollar currency is involved. It can also cover deals and other actions taking place via the Internet using U.S. computer servers.""We consider that today's situation amounts to abusive use of American law
column6: Karine Berger
column7: a lawmaker from the ruling Socialist party told Reuters in an interview
column8: calling the practices akin to ""extortion"".""We ask France and Europe to let it be known to the United States that we will no longer accept this type of behavior.""In a non-binding investigative report last week
column9: lawmakers from both the Socialist party and opposition conservatives said U.S. law appeared to be more punitive toward foreign firms than domestic ones.Although foreign firms accounted for only 30 percent of investigations opened by U.S. authorities between 1977 and 2014 under its anti-foreign bribery law
column10: 67 percent of the amount levied in fines came from foreign companies

column1: Since 2009
column2: European banks such as HSBC and Deutsche Bank have paid about $16 billion to the United States over breaches of various sanction regimes. European firms have also accounted for 14 of the 15 biggest penalties
column3: the report said.The report did not question U.S. regulators' current prosecution of Deutsche Bank over mis-selling toxic mortgage securities before the financial crisis
column4: since the actions took place in the United States.But it did say the DoJ had not taken account of the impact on the financial system that the $14 billion fine it sought from the German bank went on to have.Swiss bank Credit Suisse said on Sunday it has put five employees on leave while it investigates a tax-related matter. Swiss paper SonntagsZeitung reported that the move was connected to a U.S. probe of the bank's Israeli unit over possible tax evasion.

column1: EUROPEAN ""REARMAMENT""
Berger said Europe's response had not been forceful enough
column2: and that both the European Union and individual member states should adapt their own legislation
column3: which is why the report will be sent to counterparts at other EU parliaments.""There must be a legal rearmament in Europe
column4: so we fight on equal terms with the United States in the field of economic competition
column5: Berger said.

column1: The European Union should consider challenging parts of the U.S. sanction regime at the World Trade Organisation
column2: the report said
column3: citing a 1998 precedent when Europeans successfully forced the U.S. to back down over Congressional sanctions against Cuba
column4: Libya and Iran that could have affected European firms.The EU should update a 1996 ban on European firms complying with U.S. sanctions based on such extraterritorial legislation
column5: giving European firms a legal ""excuse"" to reject U.S. demands.European countries and institutions should also encourage the use of the euro for global transactions and strengthen the use of intelligence services for economic means.Citing the recent EU ruling asking Apple to pay up to 13 billion euros in back taxes to Ireland
column6: Berger said Europe should not be afraid to be more confrontational.""It shows Europe is perfectly capable of waging this economic war since the U.S. is only going to keep it up
column7: she said. (Editing by Leigh Thomas and Andrew Callus)"

column1: 4	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-clinton-message-analysis-idUSKCN12A2J3	A new worry for Clinton: Trump's struggles may depress Democratic voter turnout	"
By James Oliphant
| WASHINGTON

WASHINGTON Hillary Clinton's campaign is confronting an emerging risk to her presidential ambitions - if Donald Trump continues to trail her in opinion polls many Democrats may simply stay at home on Election Day.Without enough popular support
column2: Clinton would enter the White House lacking the political capital she would need to drive through her agenda. In the worst-case scenario it could cost her the presidency if Republicans turn out in big numbers on Nov. 8.     Clinton
column3: the Democratic nominee
column4: has spent much of her campaign sounding the alarm over the prospect of a President Trump. She has struggled to lay out a compelling vision for her presidency and has failed to excite key constituencies
column5: including millennials
column6: minority voters and liberal Democrats.Opinion polls show that many voters are backing Clinton primarily to stop Trump
column7: the Republican nominee
column8: from getting into the White House. If they believe he has no hope of winning
column9: then what would their motivation be to turn up at the polls? In a recent Reuters/Ipsos poll about half of all Clinton supporters said they were backing her to keep Trump from winning. By contrast
column10: just 36.5 percent said it was because of Clinton's policies and just 12.6 percent said it was because they like her personally. ""Turnout is correlated with levels of competition
column12: an elections expert at the University of Florida. ""The higher the competition
column13: the higher the turnout.""The young Americans
column16: and low-income voters who make up much of the Democratic base often need to feel motivated by a particular candidate or issue to turn out
column18: as was the case with President Barack Obama's candidacy in 2008. Clinton's campaign has long worried about voter complacency and has at every turn pushed the notion that the race is close and that Trump is unfit to be president. With her lead growing
column19: that task grows more difficult.A Reuters/Ipsos 50-state survey (carried out before Friday's release of a video tape in which Trump makes vulgar remarks about women) gave the Democratic nominee a 95 percent chance of winning the election. An NBC/Wall Street Journal poll on Monday showed Clinton with an 11-point lead nationally over Trump.

column1: Low Democratic voter turnout could leave Trump an opening in swing states. And should Clinton win the election
column2: a slim margin of victory could compound the challenge she will face in trying to govern a deeply divided nation. Clinton's campaign
column3: however
column4: will be able to rely on an extensive and well-funded voter mobilization effort
column5: one that is expected to give her an edge over Trump's smaller organization. MOVING PAST TRUMP

column1: The Clinton campaign insisted on Monday the race will remain tight. It sent out a new fundraising pitch to supporters
column2: contending that Trump is ""an authoritarian threat"" for saying at Sunday's presidential debate that she would be in jail if he was president.

column1: Clinton must also contend with anger among liberal Democrats over leaked excerpts of paid speeches she made to banks and big business. The excerpts appeared to confirm their fears about her support for global trade and tendency to cozy up to Wall Street.Some liberals have also been waiting for Clinton to make a more positive case for her own presidency.""This election cannot be just a referendum on Donald Trump
column2: said Arun Chaudhury
column3: creative director of Revolution Messaging
column4: a left-leaning consulting firm that oversaw the online media operation of former Clinton rival
column5: Senator Bernie Sanders. Clinton's central message
column6: he said
column7: has been that ""everyone has to step up and stop Donald Trump from being president
column8: not step up and make Hillary Clinton president."" ""The best campaign messages are comparative in nature
column10: a Democratic pollster who worked for Sanders' campaign. ""She can win by a bigger margin by giving a little more of an affirmative case for her presidency.""

column1: While Clinton frequently goes on the attack against Trump
column2: calling him racist
column3: sexist and dangerous
column4: her campaign insists it has been trying to get a positive
column5: policy-oriented message out.""It is hard in this campaign when you're running against him and he generates so much controversy and therefore headlines
column6: Jennifer Palmieri
column7: Clinton's communications director
column8: told Reuters. ""It's hard to break through on any one day
column9: and that's why we just have to keep at it.""The two candidates' central campaign slogans reflect their differing appeals to the electorate. Where Trump's is the change-oriented ""Make America Great Again
column10: Clinton's is a more stolid ""Stronger Together
column11: which speaks to rallying existing Democratic voters around her candidacy - and is a harder sell. Clinton's campaign seems to have recognized the need for some adjustments to its message. Since the presidential race intensified last month
column12: Clinton has returned to the style of campaigning that helped her win early states in the Democratic nominating contests
column13: holding smallish events focused on issues of most concern to core Democratic constituencies such as women and young voters. Turchin
column15: said Clinton's efforts at fashioning a positive message were improving
column16: although she is still having difficulty attracting the support of 18-to-34 year-old voters
column17: among others. ""You've got to make the hard case over and over again
column18: he said. ""She's got to convince people she shares their values."" (Reporting by James Oliphant
column21: and Emily Stephenson. Written by James Oliphant
column22: editing by Paul Thomasch and Ross Colvin)"

column1: 5	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-debate-ratings-idUSKCN12A1LF	TV audience sharply down for second Trump-Clinton debate
column2: despite tape furor	"

column1: By Jill Serjeant and Lisa Richwine
| NEW YORK/LOS ANGELES
NEW YORK/LOS ANGELES The television audience for the second debate between White House contenders Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton fell sharply from their first
column2: record-breaking encounter
column3: despite the drama caused by a 2005 video of Trump boasting about groping women.Nielsen data for 11 broadcast
column4: cable and public television channels on Monday showed that some 66.5 million Americans tuned into the bitter 90-minute debate on Sunday
column5: well below the record 84 million that watched the first face-off two weeks ago.The figures do not include millions more who watched the debate online
column6: through social media or in bars and restaurants.Second presidential debates tend to attract smaller TV audiences
column7: but attention was high going into Sunday's matchup after the emergence of the Trump video prompted several Republican politicians to abandon him. However
column8: the second debate took place in the same time slot as NBC's popular ""Sunday Night Football
column9: which was watched by about 15 million Americans
column10: Nielsen data showed. NBC did not carry the debate.

column1: While the National Football League game
column2: along with Major League Baseball play-offs
column3: likely pulled viewers away from the debate
column4: many Americans already may have made up their minds on candidates
column5: said Tom Hollihan
column6: communication professor at the University of Southern California's Annenberg School.""When we get to mid-October
column7: history tells us people have already made their decisions
column8: he said. ""They lock themselves into their viewpoints and are less open to new information.""

column1: The furor over the Trump tape and his attacks on Hillary Clinton's husband
column2: former President Bill Clinton
column3: for alleged sexual misconduct also may have turned off some viewers.Sunday's debate
column4: the second of three before the Nov. 8 election
column5: was remarkable for the brutal nature of the exchanges between Trump and Clinton
column6: his Democratic rival.  ""While in the past families might have made a commitment to watch a presidential debate
column7: I think many in this case were saying
column8: 'Why should I do that? Why should I have to answer my kids' questions about these topics?'"" Hollihan said.

column1: The TV audience ranked below the nation's top 10 most-watched presidential encounters
column2: and below that for President Barack Obama's first and second 2012 debates with Republican challenger Mitt Romney.Last week's vice presidential debate between Republican Mike Pence and Democrat Tim Kaine drew 37 million Americans - the lowest audience for a VP debate since 2000. (Reporting by Jill Serjeant and Lisa Richwine; Editing by Bill Trott and Jonathan Oatis)"

column1: 6	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-idUSKCN12A20M	Top Republican Ryan distances himself from Trump White House bid	"
By Richard Cowan and Susan Cornwell
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON Paul Ryan
column2: the top Republican in the U.S. Congress
column3: took the extraordinary step on Monday of distancing himself from Donald Trump

column6: the speaker of the House of Representatives
column7: said he would not defend Trump or campaign for him after the uproar over the New York businessman's sexually aggressive comments that surfaced on Friday.    Ryan's announcement added to the party's worst turmoil in decades and reinforced the growing sense of isolation around  Trump
column8: who has never previously run for public office.Clinton has led Trump in most national opinion polls for months and Trump's poll numbers have begun to drop further since the emergence on Friday of a video from 2005 showing the former reality TV star bragging crudely about groping women and making unwanted sexual advances.  Trump hit back at Ryan
column9: the Republican vice presidential candidate in 2012
column10: who has frequently been critical of him.    ""Paul Ryan should spend more time on balancing the budget
column11: jobs and illegal immigration and not waste his time on fighting Republican nominee
column13: who had expressed disgust over the tape and canceled a campaign event with Trump over the weekend

The speaker went back on the Republican conference call later to clarify he was not withdrawing his endorsement.Many Republican members of Congress are concerned that Trump's chaotic campaign could ruin their chances of holding their majorities in the House of Representatives and Senate in the November election and could inflict long-term damage on the party. During a weekend dominated by criticism of Trump over the lewd remarks

column11: the party's leadership and fundraising arm

Any suggestion that the RNC isn't fully supporting the Trump-Pence ticket is wrong
column2: one RNC member said
column3: describing the message. ""We are fully on board. We are going to devote every ounce of effort and resource into helping the Trump-Pence ticket win and all the other candidates up and down the ballot.""Any attempt to replace Trump on the ballot this close to Election Day would face huge legal and logistical hurdles.A defiant Trump went on the offensive in a vicious presidential debate on Sunday
column4: saying Clinton

column11: we'll continue to talk about Bill and Hillary Clinton doing inappropriate things. There are so many of them.""

column1: She goes out and says: 'I love women
column2: I'm going to help women.' She's a total hypocrite

column4: Pennsylvania.Clinton accused Trump of brushing off criticism of his comments about women. ""On Friday
column5: the whole world heard him talking about the terrible way he treats women. And last night when he was pressed about how he behaves
column6: he just doubled down on his excuse that it's just locker room banter
column7: she told a rally at Wayne State University in Detroit. The television audience for the debate fell sharply from their first
column8: record-breaking encounter in September.    Nielsen data supplied by CNN for 10 broadcast and cable channels on Monday showed that 63.6 million Americans tuned into the 90-minute debate on Sunday

column12: compared with 35 percent for Trump.    The Reuters/Ipsos State of the Nation project released on Monday estimated that Clinton had at least a 95 percent chance of winning the 270 Electoral College votes needed to become president. The polling did not capture reaction to Trump's performance in Sunday's debate or the release of the Friday videotape. (Additional reporting by Susan Cornwell
column16: Andy Sullivan and Susan Heavey; Writing by Alistair Bell and John Whitesides; Editing by Frances Kerry and Peter Cooney)"

column1: 7	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-trump-women-idUSKCN12B05K	Locker room talk? Key women voters call foul on Trump's defense	"
By Ginger Gibson and Grant Smith
| WASHINGTON/NEW YORK
WASHINGTON/NEW YORK U.S. Republican Donald Trump has dismissed his vulgar sexual comments about women that surfaced on a video as ""locker room talk
column2: but his explanation did little to soothe the queasiness of Esther Rosser
column3: a 71-year-old grandmother from Virginia.""I know he apologized
column4: and all you can do is apologize

column6: said Rosser

column1: 8	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-podesta-emails-idUSKCN12B01T	Clinton weighed reinstating Glass-Steagall
column2: Wikileaks emails show	"

column1: By Amanda Becker and Luciana Lopez

A longtime political adviser to Hillary Clinton last year urged her presidential campaign to support a new version of a law that separated commercial and investment banking to avoid antagonizing the Democratic Party's progressive wing
column2: according to emails published by Wikileaks on Monday.Mandy Grunwald
column3: an outside adviser to Clinton
column4: urged Clinton's policy team in October 2015
column5: just days before a Wall Street policy rollout
column6: to consider endorsing a new version of the Glass-Steagall Act
column7: according to an email reviewed by Reuters.The Glass-Steagall Act was a Depression-era law that prohibited commercial banks from engaging in risky trading activities. The 1933 law was repealed in 1999 during the presidency of Bill Clinton when he passed legislation removing barriers between commercial banks
column8: investment banks and insurance companies.Many Democratic activists believe that reinstating the Glass-Steagall law and breaking up large financial institutions would help prevent future financial crises such as the one that rocked the U.S. economy in 2008. Grunwald said if Clinton did not back a new Glass-Steagall
column9: she risked alienating liberal U.S. Senator Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts
column10: an outspoken critic of Wall Street who is popular in the left wing of the Democratic Party.

column1: The Clinton campaign would neither confirm nor deny the authenticity of the latest batch of hacked emails of Clinton campaign Chairman John Podesta released by Wikileaks.The U.S. government last week formally accused Russia of a campaign of cyber attacks against Democratic Party organizations
column2: a charge Russia has denied. As a result
column3: Clinton campaign officials and supporters have warned that such email releases could include fraudulent or misleading documents among genuine emails.At the time of Grunwald's email
column4: Clinton's primary debates against her then-rival U.S. Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont were fast approaching. Grunwald worried that if Clinton did not support a new Glass-Steagall law
column5: it would make it more difficult to defend her plan to curb Wall Street risk.

column1: It could also prompt Warren to endorse Sanders
column2: Grunwald wrote in the email released by Wikileaks. Grunwald said that in conversations with Clinton
column3: the former secretary of state had indicated she was ""leaning toward endorsing Glass Steagall
column4: instead of or in addition to the risk-based approach she ultimately announced.""I understand we face phoniness charges if we 'change' our position now - but we face risks this way too
column5: Grunwald wrote
column6: adding that Clinton's policy team told her it should be a political decision.

column1: In the weeks after the email
column2: Clinton announced that she would look to break up large banks based on the risk they posed to the economy
column3: not based on size alone or type of investment activity. Clinton also proposed levying a ""risk fee"" on the liabilities of banks with more than $50 billion in assets
column4: saying it was a more comprehensive approach.Democratic Party sources told Reuters on Monday they believe that around 50
column5: 000 of Podesta's emails are in the possession of Wikileaks and they expect them to be dribbled out periodically between now and the Nov. 8 election between Clinton and Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump.A previous dump of hacked emails from Podesta on Friday included what appear to be excerpts from paid speeches that Clinton made to Wall Street
column6: which her campaign had refused to release. (Reporting by Luciana Lopez in New York
column7: Amanda Becker in Detroit and Mark Hosenball in Washington; Editing by Grant McCool and Lisa Shumaker)"

The Reuters/Ipsos State of the Nation project released on Monday estimated that Clinton had at least a 95 percent chance of winning the 270 Electoral College votes needed to become president. The polling did not capture reaction to Trump's performance in Sunday's debate or the release of the Friday videotape. (Additional reporting by Susan Cornwell
